messageBody:
>
> Date: Wed, 9 Jan 2002 11:48:30 +0100
> From: "Thomas SMETS" <tsmets@...>
> Subject: Simple conceptual question when changing accessors
> of a method ...
> [...]
>
> I'd like now to change the accessor of some methods from public to
> "friendly" or protected for some methods as they are not
> needed for the
> caller anymore.
> My question is twofold :
> 1°. What are the possibilities ?
> Would simply moving the TestCase as inner
> class suite the matter.

This would solve the problem in some ways, in that you could access the
private and friendly methods, but but in other ways it's not optimal.
Including the testing code in the same class as the production code both
bloats your production code and creates a direct dependancy on JUnit,
meaning that when you ship the code you have to either creatively strip out
the unit test class files with Ant when you ship, or ship JUnit with it.

In the case of this certification, (which I recently passed myself, btw), I
think it would mean that you would have to submit JUnit with your code in
order that the examiner would be able to compile it. I don't think the rules
of the exam allow you to submit code that you havn't written, or introduce
dependancies on 3rd party products. I got round it myself by submitting the
test code as "developer documentation" and not including the JUnit jar, just
a note to download it if the examiner wanted to compile or run the tests.
Needless to say I got 20/20 for documentation :-)

> 2°. Am I'm better to make all the TestCases member
> of the package of the class to test & make the accessor
> protected ?
>

I personally think this is a better approach - put the tests in the same
package but in a different source tree, and make the methods package or
protected level. I think someone else mentioned that Ant makes that easier
to handle. Of course probably the best approach of all has already been
outlined - make the methods public on another class that you can test. I've
personally found though that it's not always obvious how to do that, and it
is useful to be able to test package and protected methods.

hope that helps,

Emily
